title: Embrace hydrogen-fuelled trains and buses
text:
The UK operates hydrogen buses and ferries, with Australia's Transit Systems operating a fleet of 10 hydrogen buses for Transport for London.

Reducing the transport sector's carbon emissions by encouraging greater deployment of zero-emission vehicles like hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicles (FCEVs) would help Australia meet its international commitments on climate change, the Council of Australian Governments' energy group said in an issues paper released in July as it prepares a national hydrogen strategy.

The council has identified urban buses, passenger ferries, long haul freight, light vehicles and remote mine site vehicles as prospective early use cases for FCEVs.

Canberra will be the first Australian city to pilot a publicly-accessible hydrogen vehicle refuelling station, which will be used by 20 FCEVs that will be added to the ACT Government fleet as well as private hydrogen-fuelled vehicles. The Queensland government is also adding hydrogen cars to its fleet.

Keolis claims it will operate more fully electric transport networks in France by the end of the year than any other company as it picks up more contracts, including managing 43 fully electric buses in the northern French city of Amiens.

In Australia, where Keolis operates in a joint venture with Downer EDI, the group plans to bid for the proposed third stage of the Gold Coast light rail line G:link if the Queensland government secures enough funding to go ahead with the project.

Keolis Downer already operates the first two stages of G:link as well as Melbourne's Yarra trams and buses in South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland.

Australia remains an attractive market, Mr Tabary said. "You can sense that this country is booming with population growth and an urbanisation agenda."

The integrated public transport model adopted by Newcastle, where Keolis Downer manages the city's buses, ferry and light rail systems and its trialling on-demand services, is likely to be adopted by other medium-sized cities if the Newcastle project proves to be a long-term success, he said.

Adelaide has put out a tender calling for a single group to operate both its buses and trams as it privatises more of its transport networks.
description: French transport operator Keolis says hydrogen-fuelled cars, buses and trains are on their way as governments slash greenhouse gases.
